title: Hans-Martin Heyn
text:
I’m a senior lecturer at the Computer Science and Engineering Department of the University of Gothenburg and Chalmers University of Technology in Sweden. My research concentrates around Software Engineering for AI and distributed cyber-physical systems. I’m especially interested in studying how we can set requirements for training data and data at runtime based on prior knowledge we have about the problem domain. A research direction that triggered my interest for achieving this aim is causal modelling and information entropy. I’m teaching the courses DIT357: Distributed Systems and DAT550 / DIT978: Advanced Software Engineering for AI/ML-Enabled Systems. I’m also giving guest lectures in DIT633: Development of Embedded and Real-Time Systems.
On this site I keep a list of my publications, my CV, a list of my services and a list of theses I supervise. Feel free to contact me if you have questions.
I am on parental leave until April 2026 which is why I do not offer regular office hours at the moment. If you have a question or request regarding my research or teaching, please send me an e-mail. I will answer as soon as possible given that my little daughter allows me a moment of time :).



Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim, Norway
Ph.D. in Marine Cybernetics | September 2014 - October 2018 | Thesis: Motion Sensing on Vessels Operating in Sea Ice.
RWTH Aachen University, Aachen, Germany
M.Sc. Management, Business and Economics | October 2013 - March 2016 | Thesis: Route planning algorithm for electric logistic fleets in consideration of battery degradation.
M.Sc., Electrical Engineering, Information Technology and Computer Engineering | October 2010 - September 2013 | Thesis: Adaptive State- and Parameter Estimation for Lithium-Ion Batteries.
B.Sc., Electrical Engineering, Information Technology and Computer Engineering | October 2007 - September 2010 | Thesis: Safety concepts for high voltage battery storage systems.





Causal models for specifying requirements in industrial ML-based software: A case study. HM Heyn, Y Mao, R Weiß, E Knauss. 2025. Journal of Software and Systems (JSS). https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jss.2025.112691
An empirical investigation of challenges of specifying training data and runtime monitor requirements for critical machine learning software and their relationship to architecture decisions. HM Heyn, E Knauss, I Malleswaran, S Dinakaran, Requirements Engineering. 2024. Springer Requirement Engineering Journal, 1-24. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00766-024-00415-4.
Identifying and managing data quality requirements: a design science study in the field of automated driving. SK Pradhan, HM Heyn, E Knauss. 2023. Springer Software Quality Journal, 1-48. https://doi.org/10.1007/s11219-023-09622-8
A Compositional Approach to Creating Architecture Frameworks with an Application to Distributed AI Systems. HM Heyn, E Knauss, P Pelliccione. 2023. Journal of Software and Systems (JSS). https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jss.2022.111604.

title: Hans-Martin Heyn
text:
THP-2026-1: Master Thesis: Early detection of tipping points in software engineering.
THP-2026-2: Bachelor Thesis: A quality aware and automated selection pipeline for time-lapse data in ecology.
THP-2026-3: Bachelor Thesis: Cognition support in high-stake decision making: Combining modern AI image recognition with large language models.
Please contact me by e-mail if you are interested in writing a thesis in my research group.
An overview of further available thesis topics is published on our institute’s project website.

title: Hans-Martin Heyn
text:
I currently do not have any open thesis topics. If you are interested in a thesis and you have a fantastic research idea, please contact me and we can discuss how to define a thesis out of your idea.



TH-2024-1: Explore how data needs / requirements are communicated between (ML) model-developers and experimenters in environmental research and investigate ways to improve this communication.
TH-2024-2: Investigate the reporting of data quality aspects in data portals and databases used for obtaining training data for ML models in environental research.
TH-2024-3: Investigate how to structure requirements for automotive perception systems and inter-relate between them especially in relation to safety aspects and fairness.
TH-2024-4: Studying an architectural pattern for deep learning code in the automotive industry.
TH-2024-5: Explore causal models as a way to improve scientific grounding for studies on designing defect / fault detection.



TH-5: Exploring Automated Early Problem Identification Based on Diagnostic Trouble Codes. S Forsman, Y. Yang. 2024
TH-4: Non-functional Requirements and their Impact on AGV based Systems. V Svensson, M Roudsari. 2023
TH-3: Challenges in Specifying Safety-Critical Systems with AI-Components. I Malleswaren, S Dinakaran. 2022
TH-2: Quality Attributes of Data in Distributed Deep Learning Architectures. SK Pradhan, S Tungal. 2021. Full text
TH-1: Deriving Contextual Definition and Requirements from Use Cases of Autonomous Drive. J Linder, P Subbiah. 2021. Full text
